wise_refusal: The claim is flawed because it ignores baseline attrition. Because marginal sellers (Z) are more likely to both exit and be affected by fees, the causal impact of the hike cannot be identified without controlling for pre-existing seller health.
gold_rationale: This is a Selection Bias error. Platform fees cause attrition among marginal participants. Attributing the exit solely to the fee without accounting for pre-existing profitability trends leads to a biased estimate of policy impact.

scenario: After capital controls are imposed, the exchange rate becomes less volatile. A policymaker claims: â€œCapital controls stabilized the currency.â€
claim: Capital controls stabilized the currency.
label: NO

Z: External financial shocks and foreign reserve adequacy

causal_structure: External shocks (Z) increase volatility (Y) and motivate the government to impose controls (X). If shocks subside naturally, the currency stabilizes regardless of the policy.
key_insight: Stabilization often follows the peaking of a crisis. If controls are enacted at the peak, the policymaker is crediting the policy for a natural reduction in external pressure.
hidden_timestamp: Did the external financial shocks (Z) begin to subside or did reserves improve before the capital controls (X) were fully implemented?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the volatility was persistent and only dropped after the controls effectively blocked speculative flows, the claim could be [VALID].
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If global market conditions improved first, then the stabilization (Y) was due to external factors (Z), making the claim [INVALID].

wise_refusal: The claim is flawed because it ignores the business cycle of shocks. Because both volatility and policy response are driven by external pressure (Z), the causal impact of controls cannot be identified without isolating it from global market trends.
gold_rationale: This is a Confounding via Mediator error. Macroeconomic policies (X) are often endogenous to crisis cycles (Z). Without controlling for the subsiding of the original shock, the policymaker wrongly attributes stabilization to the intervention.

scenario: After a subsidy for automation equipment is introduced, employment rises in high-skill jobs but falls in routine tasks. A policymaker claims: â€œThe subsidy caused job polarization.â€
claim: The subsidy caused job polarization.
label: NO
causal_structure: Technological readiness (Z) drives both the adoption of automation (Y) and the decision of the government to subsidize it (X). Polarization is a structural trend driven by tech progress.
key_insight: Polarization is often already underway due to falling robot prices. If subsidies are introduced to 'keep up' with tech trends, the policy is a symptom, not the cause.
hidden_timestamp: Did the shift in employment toward high-skill tasks (Y) begin before the automation subsidy (X) was enacted?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the labor market was stable and only polarized following the financial incentive, the claim could be [VALID].
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the trend was already visible, then technological progress (Z) is the cause of both the labor shift and the policy, and the claim is [INVALID].

wise_refusal: The claim is flawed because it ignores technological endogeneity. Because both polarization and subsidies respond to the readiness of automation technology (Z), the causal impact of the policy cannot be identified without isolating it from the broader innovation cycle.
gold_rationale: This is a Confounding via Mediator error. Subsidies (X) are often endogenous to technology cycles (Z). Without controlling for the exogenous trend of automation, the policymaker wrongly attributes the labor market shift entirely to the policy.

scenario: After a rationing rule is introduced for a subsidized good, reported demand falls. An administrator claims: â€œRationing caused demand to decrease.â€
claim: Rationing caused demand to decrease.
label: NO
causal_structure: Rationing (X) may increase the stigma (Z) associated with the good, causing users to stop reporting demand (Y). True demand may be unchanged, but measurement is biased.
key_insight: Measurement depends on participation. If the rule makes people 'hide' their demand to avoid stigma or bureaucracy, the administrator is observing a reporting error, not a demand shift.
hidden_timestamp: Did the social stigma or participation cost (Z) increase before the reported demand (Y) began to fall following the rationing (X)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the rationing effectively reduced the utility of the good for all users, causing a genuine drop in desire to consume, the claim could be [VALID].
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If stigma rose first, then Z is the cause of the drop in reported volume, making the claim [INVALID].

wise_refusal: The claim is flawed because it ignores selection into measurement. Because both participation and reported demand respond to the costs of the rationing system (Z), the causal impact of the rule on true demand cannot be identified.
gold_rationale: This is a Selection Bias error. Rationing (X) often changes who participates in the reporting system. If the data is only captured for those who navigate the new rules, 'reported demand' no longer reflects 'true demand'.

scenario: After automatic enrollment into a retirement plan is introduced, average savings rise. An organizer claims: â€œDefault enrollment caused people to save more.â€
claim: Default enrollment caused people to save more.
label: NO
causal_structure: Patience and literacy (Z) drive both the likelihood of staying in a plan (X) and the general savings behavior (Y). High-literacy workers stay enrolled because they understand the benefit.
key_insight: Savings rise because the default keeps the 'right' people in. If the only people who don't opt-out are those who already intended to save, the default isn't changing behavior.
hidden_timestamp: Did the high-literacy workers (Z) already exhibit high savings in other accounts before the automatic enrollment (X) began?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the default successfully brought in low-literacy workers who previously saved nothing, the claim could be [VALID].
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If they were already savers, then literacy (Z) is the cause of both enrollment and savings, making the claim [INVALID].

wise_refusal: The claim is flawed because it ignores selection into retention. Because both enrollment and savings rates respond to time preference (Z), the causal impact of the default cannot be identified without controlling for opt-out behavior.
gold_rationale: This is a Confounding via Mediator error. Defaults (X) interact with worker traits (Z). Without controlling for the systematic differences between those who opt-out and those who stay, the organizer wrongly attributes the savings rate solely to the default mechanism.

scenario: After a funding reform for hospitals, average patient recovery rates improve. A policymaker claims: â€œThe reform caused better health outcomes.â€
claim: The reform caused better health outcomes.
label: NO

Z: Baseline patient severity and staff quality

causal_structure: High-quality hospitals (Z) are more likely to participate in reforms (X) and naturally have higher recovery rates (Y). This creates a selection bias in the participating hospitals.
key_insight: Recovery rates are determined by staff quality. If the reform only attracts hospitals that already have great staff, the policymaker is observing hospital quality, not reform efficacy.
hidden_timestamp: Did the high staff quality (Z) exist before the hospitals joined the funding reform (X)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the funding allowed poorly-performing hospitals to hire new experts and buy new equipment, raising recovery, the claim could be [VALID].
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If they were already high-performing, then Z is the cause of both participation and health outcomes, making the claim [INVALID].

wise_refusal: The claim is flawed because it ignores selection bias. Hospitals with better staff and less severe cases (Z) both join the reform and have better outcomes, confounding the reform's actual causal impact.
gold_rationale: This is a Selection Bias error. High-quality institutions (Z) self-select into policy reforms (X). Attributing health outcomes to the reform without controlling for baseline hospital quality leads to a biased estimate of policy impact.

scenario: After a pollution tax is imposed, some firms relocate production. A regulator claims: â€œThe tax caused firms to move.â€
claim: The tax caused firms to move.
label: NO

Z: Pre-existing cost disadvantage and competitive pressure

causal_structure: Declining competitiveness (Z) drives firms to relocate (Y) and simultaneously leads the government to enact pollution taxes (X) to transition the economy.
key_insight: Firms often move because they are already losing money. If the tax is the final straw, but the trend was set by international competition, the tax is not the primary cause.
hidden_timestamp: Did the international competitive pressure and cost disadvantages (Z) emerge before the pollution tax (X) was implemented?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the firms were highly profitable and stable, and moved only to avoid the new specific tax burden, the claim could be [VALID].
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If relocation plans were already in motion due to competition, then Z is the cause of both the move and the policy environment, making the claim [INVALID].

wise_refusal: The claim is flawed because it ignores industrial endogeneity. Because both relocation and taxation respond to the competitiveness of the industry (Z), the causal impact of the tax cannot be identified without isolating it from global market trends.
gold_rationale: This is a Reverse Causality error. Environmental taxes (X) are often endogenous to industrial decline (Z). Without controlling for the underlying competitive disadvantage of the firms, the regulator wrongly attributes the relocation solely to the tax.

scenario: After firms are required to accept digital payments, reported tax revenue increases. A finance official claims: â€œThe digital payment mandate caused tax compliance to rise.â€
claim: The digital payment mandate caused tax compliance to rise.
label: NO

Z: Pre-existing enforcement intensity and informal sector dynamics

causal_structure: Tightening enforcement (Z) leads firms to report more income (Y) to avoid penalties and simultaneously makes a digital payment mandate (X) a viable tool for the state.
key_insight: Revenue growth is often the result of broader administrative audits. If the mandate is just one part of a wider enforcement push, its independent causal effect is overstated.
hidden_timestamp: Did the increase in tax audits and enforcement intensity (Z) precede the legislative mandate for digital payments (X)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the mandate successfully digitized previously 'dark' cash transactions in a stable enforcement environment, raising revenue through traceability, the claim could be [VALID].
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If audits increased first, then revenue growth (Y) was driven by fear of penalties (Z), and the claim that the mandate caused the rise is [INVALID].

wise_refusal: The claim is flawed because it ignores the endogeneity of tax policy. Because both reported revenue and payment mandates respond to the latent intensity of state enforcement (Z), the causal impact of the mandate cannot be identified without isolating it from the broader administrative cycle.
gold_rationale: This is a Confounding via Enforcement error. Mandates (X) are often endogenous to tax administration cycles (Z). Without controlling for the exogenous shift in audit intensity, the official wrongly attributes the revenue increase entirely to the digital payment mandate.

scenario: After social insurance coverage is expanded, self-employment rises. A researcher claims: â€œSocial insurance caused more people to start businesses.â€
claim: Social insurance caused more people to start businesses.
label: NO

Z: Underlying labor market risk and economic volatility

causal_structure: Rising labor market risk (Z) pushes workers into necessity-based self-employment (Y) and simultaneously forces governments to expand social safety nets (X) to mitigate the crisis.
key_insight: Self-employment often rises during economic downturns. If insurance is expanded as a counter-cyclical response, the policy is a reaction to the same risk that drove the labor shift.
hidden_timestamp: Did the increase in labor market volatility and layoffs (Z) precede the legislative expansion of social insurance (X)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the economy was stable and the expansion of insurance reduced the 'downside risk' of entrepreneurship, leading to a surge in startups, the claim could be [VALID].
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If layoffs and market risk increased first, then the rise in self-employment (Y) was a survival response to the economy (Z), making the claim [INVALID].

wise_refusal: The claim is flawed because it ignores the endogeneity of social policy. Because both self-employment and insurance expansion respond to underlying labor market risk (Z), the causal impact of the reform cannot be identified without isolating it from the broader economic cycle.
gold_rationale: This is a Reverse Causality error. Social welfare reforms (X) are often endogenous to labor market shocks (Z). Without controlling for the exogenous shift in market risk, the researcher wrongly attributes the entrepreneurial surge to the policy itself.

scenario: After a region receives a large infrastructure grant, average wages rise. A development official claims: â€œThe grant caused wages to increase.â€
claim: The grant caused wages to increase.
label: NO

Z: Pre-existing growth fundamentals and skill composition

causal_structure: Growth fundamentals (Z) attract investment and raise wages (Y) while also making the region a prime candidate for federal or international grants (X).
key_insight: Grants are often 'performance-based' or targeted at high-potential areas. If a grant is given to a fast-growing city, the official is crediting the policy for a trend that was already in motion.
hidden_timestamp: Did the trend of rising wages and private sector investment (Z) emerge before the region was selected for the infrastructure grant (X)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the region was in structural decline and the grant-funded project directly reduced transport costs and attracted new industries, the claim could be [VALID].
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the region was already booming, then the fundamentals (Z) caused both the grant and the wage rise, and the claim is [INVALID].

wise_refusal: The claim is flawed because it ignores the targeting of development aid. Because both wage growth and grant allocation respond to a region's economic potential (Z), the causal impact of the grant cannot be identified without isolating it from the underlying growth trend.
gold_rationale: This is a Reverse Causality error. Development grants (X) are often endogenous to regional growth prospects (Z). Without controlling for the pre-existing economic trajectory, the official wrongly attributes the wage growth entirely to the infrastructure funding.

scenario: After a disaster relief fund is allocated, business activity in affected areas rebounds. An official claims: â€œThe relief fund caused the recovery.â€
claim: The relief fund caused the recovery.
label: NO

Z: Initial damage severity and pre-existing economic resilience

causal_structure: Relief funds (X) are often targeted at areas with specific damage profiles (Z). If areas with milder damage recover faster (Y) regardless of the aid, the official wrongly attributes the rebound to the policy.
key_insight: Recovery momentum is often set by the scale of the initial shock. Without a strategy to separate the 'natural rebound' from the aid, the policy's causal effect is unidentifiable.
hidden_timestamp: Did business activity (Y) begin to stabilize or show signs of rebound in resilient areas before the disaster relief (X) was disbursed?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the rebound only occurred after a significant liquidity injection that allowed shuttered businesses to reopen, the claim could be [VALID].
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If business activity showed early signs of recovery before the aid, then resilience (Z) is the primary driver of both outcomes, making the claim [INVALID].

wise_refusal: The claim is flawed because it ignores endogenous targeting. Because both business activity and funding levels respond to the initial severity of the disaster (Z), the causal impact of the aid cannot be identified without isolating it from the natural rebound trend.
gold_rationale: This is a Reverse Causality error. Relief allocation (X) is endogenous to disaster severity (Z). Without controlling for the pre-existing economic resilience and natural recovery trends of the affected region, the official wrongly attributes the activity rebound entirely to the funding.

scenario: After an export ban on a staple good is imposed, domestic prices rise. A regulator claims: â€œThe export ban caused prices to increase.â€
claim: The export ban caused prices to increase.
label: NO

Z: Global supply shocks and domestic storage expectations

causal_structure: Supply shocks (Z) drive up prices (Y) and force regulators to enact bans (X) to protect domestic supply. The ban is a symptom of the shock, not the cause of the initial price spike.
key_insight: Commodity prices are highly sensitive to global supply. If a ban is enacted during a shortage, the regulator is crediting the policy for a price trend already set by the global market.
hidden_timestamp: Did the global supply disruption (Z) occur before the legislative implementation of the export ban (X)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the market was stable and the ban caused a sudden domestic supply glut followed by an unexpected hoarding-driven price spike, the claim could be [VALID].
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If prices were already climbing due to global shortages, then the shock (Z) is the cause of both the ban and the price level, making the claim [INVALID].

wise_refusal: The claim is flawed because it ignores policy endogeneity. Because both price levels and trade bans respond to underlying supply shocks (Z), the causal impact of the ban cannot be identified without isolating it from the broader commodity cycle.
gold_rationale: This is a Reverse Causality error. Trade interventions (X) are endogenous to supply shocks (Z). Without controlling for the pre-existing upward pressure on prices from global shortages, the regulator wrongly attributes the price level entirely to the ban.

scenario: After an energy-efficiency subsidy is introduced, total household electricity consumption rises. A critic claims: â€œThe subsidy caused people to use more electricity.â€
claim: The subsidy caused people to use more electricity.
label: NO

Z: Household income growth and appliance replacement cycles

causal_structure: Rising wealth (Z) leads to more electricity use (Y) and also increases the uptake of subsidized green tech (X). This creates a 'rebound effect' where efficiency is offset by increased usage.
key_insight: Consumption is driven by affordability. If subsidies are taken up by households whose incomes are also rising, the policy effect is confounded by the general increase in living standards.
hidden_timestamp: Did the increase in household disposable income (Z) precede the implementation of the energy-efficiency subsidy (X)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the subsidy made electricity so cheap at the margin that it induced a massive behavioral shift in consumption, the claim could be [VALID].
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If income was already rising, then wealth (Z) is the primary driver of both tech adoption and usage (Y), making the claim [INVALID].

wise_refusal: The claim is flawed because it ignores the income effect. Because both consumption and subsidy uptake respond to household wealth (Z), the causal impact of the policy cannot be identified without isolating it from the broader economic cycle.
gold_rationale: This is a Confounding via Mediator error. Behavioral responses to efficiency (rebound effects) are often endogenous to income growth (Z). Without controlling for the exogenous shift in wealth, the critic wrongly blames the subsidy for the consumption increase.

scenario: Startups accepted into an incubator have higher survival and revenue growth than rejected applicants. The incubator claims: â€œAdmission caused startups to succeed.â€
claim: Admission caused startups to succeed.
label: NO

Z: Founder experience and product-market fit quality

causal_structure: High-quality founders (Z) are more likely to be admitted to incubators (X) and are also more likely to succeed (Y). This creates a collider bias when comparing admitted vs. rejected groups.
key_insight: Admission is a signal of pre-existing quality. If incubators cherry-pick the best teams, the success observed is a result of selection, not necessarily the incubation services provided.
hidden_timestamp: Were the founder experience and product-market fit (Z) determined before the incubator admission decision (X)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the incubator provided a specific network pivot that allowed an average team to achieve exponential growth, the claim could be [VALID].
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the team was already high-performing, then quality (Z) is the cause of both admission and success, making the claim [INVALID].

wise_refusal: The claim is flawed because it ignores selection on latent quality. Because both admission and success respond to founder capability (Z), comparing admitted and rejected startups yields a biased causal estimate of the incubator's effect.
gold_rationale: This is a Selection Bias error. Venture programs (X) select on pre-existing excellence (Z). Attributing success to the program without controlling for the 'unobservable' quality of the applicants leads to a biased estimate of the program's value-add.

scenario: After school boundaries are redrawn, average test scores at a school rise. The district claims: â€œThe zoning reform improved educational quality.â€
claim: The zoning reform improved educational quality.
label: NO

Y.name: Average test scores at the school

Z: Student socioeconomic background and neighborhood sorting

causal_structure: Zoning changes (X) alter the demographic composition of students (Z). If higher-scoring students are sorted into the school, the average score (Y) rises mechanically without any change in teaching quality.
key_insight: Averages depend on the pool. If a reform simply swaps one student body for another, the district is observing the result of demographic sorting, not academic improvement.
hidden_timestamp: Did the socioeconomic profile and pre-existing score distribution of the new student body (Z) differ from the previous group before the zoning change (X)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the student body remained the same and scores rose after new curriculum investments were made following the zoning, the claim could be [VALID].
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If high-scoring students were moved into the zone, then demographics (Z) is the cause of the rise in scores (Y), making the claim [INVALID].

wise_refusal: The claim is flawed because it ignores student sorting. Because both zoning and average scores respond to the socioeconomic composition of the student body (Z), the causal impact on educational quality cannot be identified from aggregate test scores alone.
gold_rationale: This is a Selection Bias error. Educational outcomes are highly correlated with student background (Z). If a zoning change (X) selects for high-background students, the school's average performance (Y) will rise regardless of any changes in school quality.

scenario: After a new triage rule is introduced, average treatment cost per patient falls. Administrators claim: â€œThe rule reduced treatment costs.â€
claim: The rule reduced treatment costs.
label: NO

Z: Baseline patient severity and case-mix distribution

causal_structure: Triage rules (X) determine which patients are admitted (Z). If a rule selects for less severe cases, the average cost (Y) will fall even if treatment for each specific condition remains unchanged.
key_insight: Health costs are driven by patient severity. If a rule 'optimizes' by admitting easier cases, the administrators are observing a change in the sample, not an increase in efficiency.
hidden_timestamp: Did the distribution of patient severity (Z) among the admitted group change following the implementation of the new triage rule (X)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the patient mix was stable and costs fell because the triage rule streamlined resource allocation for the same severity levels, the claim could be [VALID].
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the hospital started admitting lower-severity patients, then the case-mix (Z) is the cause of the lower average cost (Y), making the claim [INVALID].

wise_refusal: The claim is flawed because it ignores selection on admission. Because both treatment costs and admission status respond to patient severity (Z), the causal impact of the rule on medical efficiency cannot be identified from aggregate cost averages.
gold_rationale: This is a Selection Bias error. Medical costs are endogenous to patient severity (Z). If a triage rule (X) selects for low-severity patients, the average treatment cost (Y) will fall mechanically. Without controlling for the case-mix, the administrators wrongly credit the rule for efficiency gains.

scenario: After banks are required to hold more capital, lending growth slows. A regulator claims: â€œHigher capital requirements caused a credit contraction.â€
claim: Higher capital requirements caused a credit contraction.
label: NO

Z: Macroeconomic outlook and default risk expectations

causal_structure: Economic downturns (Z) lead to slower lending (Y) and also prompt regulators to tighten capital requirements (X) to build resilience. This makes policy timing endogenous to the credit cycle.
key_insight: Regulation is often a reaction to risk. If requirements are tightened during a period of rising defaults, the regulator is crediting the policy for a slowdown that the market was already conducting.
hidden_timestamp: Did the deterioration in the macroeconomic outlook and rising default risk (Z) precede the legislative implementation of the higher requirements (X)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the economy was growing and the regulator tightened independent of risk to curb a bubble, causing an immediate drop in lending, the claim could be [VALID].
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If risk rose first, then the credit slowdown (Y) was a market reaction to the macro outlook (Z), making the claim [INVALID].

wise_refusal: The claim is flawed because it ignores regulatory endogeneity. Because both lending behavior and capital rules respond to the underlying economic outlook (Z), the causal impact of the regulation cannot be identified without isolating it from the credit cycle.
gold_rationale: This is a Confounding via Mediator error. Financial regulations (X) are endogenous to the credit cycle (Z). Without controlling for the exogenous shift in default risk, the regulator wrongly attributes the credit contraction entirely to the capital requirement.

scenario: A survey of LinkedIn professionals who are 'open to work' finds that job search is easy. A commentator claims: â€œLabor market dynamics are so robust that even in a recession, search would be easy for these workers.â€
claim: Labor market dynamics are so robust that even in a recession, search would be easy for these workers.
label: NO

X.name: Sampling restricted to currently employed, LinkedIn-active users

Y.name: Inference about general labor market ease

Z: Underlying employability and professional network strength

causal_structure: The survey samples a highly-employable subgroup (Z). This group is more likely to be on LinkedIn (X) and find jobs easily (Y). Generalizing from this group to a recession scenario is a fundamental sampling error.
key_insight: Employed professionals with active networks are the least affected by labor market shifts. Generalizing their experience to the whole economy ignores the selection bias of the sample.
hidden_timestamp: Does the sample exclude unemployed and discouraged workers who lack the network strength (Z) of the currently employed LinkedIn group?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If LinkedIn activity itself created the market robustness for all users regardless of their prior network, the claim might be [VALID].
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If network strength (Z) existed before the survey, then the sample is biased toward high-employability individuals, making the claim [INVALID].

wise_refusal: The claim is flawed because it ignores platform selection bias. Because both job search ease and LinkedIn activity respond to a worker's pre-existing network strength (Z), the survey results cannot be generalized to the broader labor market under different macro regimes.
gold_rationale: This is a Selection Bias error. Sampling is restricted to a subgroup with high employability (Z). Generalizing from this 'elite' sample to a macro-economic counterfactual (recession) fails to account for the systematic exclusion of those most vulnerable to market shocks.

scenario: A central bank runs a household inflation-expectations survey by calling landline numbers in urban areas. The surveyed households report stable expectations around 2%. The bank concludes that 'inflation expectations are well anchored across the population.'
claim: If we extended this landline-based survey for the next five years, it would continue to accurately represent the inflation expectations of the entire population.
label: NO

X.name: Sampling frame restricted to urban landline owners

Y.name: Accuracy of national inflation expectation inference

Z: Demographic shifts toward mobile-only and rural households

causal_structure: Demographic status (Z) determines both the presence of a landline (X) and the actual inflation experience/expectations (Y). As the population shifts away from landlines, the sample becomes an increasingly biased representation of a shrinking demographic.
key_insight: Representativeness is not static. If the sampling technology (landlines) is correlated with age and location, the survey ignores the groups most likely to experience volatile price shocks.
hidden_timestamp: Did the divergence between mobile-only and landline-using households' consumption baskets emerge before the survey period (X)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the whole population used landlines and only recently began to diverge in expectations following the survey implementation, the claim might have been temporarily valid. [N/A]
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If younger, mobile-only households already faced higher rent/food inflation, then the sampling frame (X) was biased from the start, making the claim [INVALID].

wise_refusal: The claim is flawed because it ignores structural coverage error. Because landline ownership is caused by demographic traits (Z) that also influence inflation exposure, the survey results are 'lying' by omission of the most vulnerable segments of the economy.
gold_rationale: This is a Selection Bias (F1/T1) error. The survey conditions on landline ownership (X), which is a non-random trait correlated with age and urban stability (Z). Because mobile-only and rural households are systematically excluded, the inference (Y) cannot be generalized to the population, especially as the coverage error worsens over time.

scenario: An online brokerage app analyzes the accounts of its active users over age 50 and finds 70% are on track for retirement. It publishes a report claiming 'most people approaching retirement are financially on track.'
claim: If we had access to every 50+ individual in the country, the share of people on track for retirement would look roughly the same as in our active-user data.
label: NO

X.name: Sampling only active brokerage app users

Y.name: Inference about general population retirement readiness

causal_structure: Financial literacy/income (Z) causes individuals to both use investment apps (X) and have higher retirement savings (Y). The app's data is pre-conditioned on the very traits that ensure success.
key_insight: User data is not population data. An investment app is a 'filter' for the most prepared individuals; those most at risk are exactly the ones who don't use such platforms.
hidden_timestamp: Did the financial engagement and literacy (Z) exist before the users opened their accounts on the brokerage app (X)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the app's UI itself created the literacy and forced previously unprepared people to save, the claim could be [VALID].
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If literacy drove the app adoption, then Z is the cause of both participation and preparedness, making the claim [INVALID].

wise_refusal: The claim is flawed because it ignores self-selection into financial services. Because participation in the app is caused by the same traits (Z) that drive retirement success, the resulting sample is upwardly biased and non-representative.
gold_rationale: This is a Selection Bias (F1/T1) error. Brokerage users are a self-selected group with higher engagement (Z). By extrapolating from this group to the general population (Y), the report fails to account for the millions of individuals without accounts who are likely far less prepared.

scenario: A private equity (PE) fund evaluates its strategy by looking at the 50 companies still in its portfolio in 2025. It notes that 70% of these portfolio companies have IRRs above 15%. Failed investmentsâ€”those written off or exited at a lossâ€”were liquidated and removed from the dashboard. The partners claim: 'Our strategy reliably produces high-IRR deals.'
claim: If we had included all historic deals in our performance analysis, our conclusion that the strategy reliably produces 15%+ IRRs would remain valid.
label: NO

X.name: Conditioning the analytic sample on survival (active portfolio status)

Z: Historical deal outcomes including total failures and liquidations

causal_structure: Deal outcome (Z) determines both the IRR (Y) and whether the company is still in the portfolio (X). By excluding the 'dead' deals, the denominator of the success rate is artificially shrunk to only include winners.
key_insight: Strategy reliability is defined by the full distribution of outcomes. If losers are removed from the data, the observed reliability is an artifact of the filter, not the investment process.
hidden_timestamp: Did the liquidation of poor-performing companies (Z) happen before the final performance audit (X) in 2025?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the audit happened at inception (impossible for IRR) or before any failures occurred, the sample would be complete, but the IRRs would be speculative. [N/A]
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If deals were liquidated throughout the fund's life, the 2025 dashboard is a survivor-only sample, making the claim [INVALID].

wise_refusal: The claim is flawed because it ignores the 'invisible graveyard' of private equity. Because deal presence in the database is caused by deal success (Z), the resulting sample is upwardly biased and cannot be used to generalize the reliability of the fund's strategy.
gold_rationale: This is a Survivorship Bias (F1/T2) error. In asset management, IRR is conditional on survival. By removing liquidated deals (X) from the dataset, the partners are calculating success on a non-random subset of high-performers (Z). Including the full historical record would mechanically lower the aggregate IRR.

scenario: A mutual fund backtests a strategy using only stocks currently listed with continuous price history from 2000 to 2025. It claims following this strategy would have comfortably beaten the market with low drawdowns.
claim: If we included all originally eligible stocks in 2000, including those that later went bankrupt or were delisted, the backtested performance would persist.
label: NO

Z: Financial health and solvency of firms

causal_structure: Firm solvency (Z) determines both the stock return (Y) and whether the data still exists in a 'survivor-only' database (X). This removes all -100% returns from the history.
key_insight: A backtest on survivors is a simulation of a trader with a crystal ball who knows which firms won't fail. It understates risk by deleting the failures from the record.
hidden_timestamp: Did the bankruptcies of the ineligible stocks (Z) occur during the backtest window (X)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If no failures occurred during the window, the sample would be complete, though this is counter-factual for a 25-year market window. [N/A]
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If firms failed throughout the 25-year period, the data is conditioned on survival, making the claim [INVALID].

wise_refusal: The claim is flawed because it ignores the 'look-ahead' bias inherent in survivors. Because presence in the current database is caused by firm survival (Z), the backtest represents an impossible investment strategy that avoids all bankruptcy by design.
gold_rationale: This is a Survivorship Bias (F1/T2) error. In quantitative finance, conditioning on continuous availability (X) removes firms that experienced catastrophic losses (Z). Including these failures would systematically lower average returns and significantly increase observed drawdowns.

scenario: A conference studies 20 unicorn founders and concludes that 'low sleep and heavy marketing' are the keys to building a billion-dollar company, ignoring thousands who did the same and failed.
claim: If we studied all founders, not just successful ones, we would still find that low sleep and heavy marketing strongly predict unicorn outcomes.
label: NO

X.name: Conditioning the study only on successful founders

Y.name: Predictive power of specific founder behaviors

causal_structure: Luck and timing (Z) often determine the unicorn outcome (Y) and whether the founder is invited to the conference (X). Many founders with the same 'playbook' but different luck never make it into the sample.
key_insight: Behaviors common among winners are only 'predictors' if they are rare among losers. If every failed founder also worked 20 hours a day, the behavior has zero predictive value.
hidden_timestamp: Did the failure of the 'unobserved' founders who used the same strategy (Z) occur before the selection of the conference panel (X)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the panel was chosen at startup inception (before outcomes), the behaviors could be tracked prospectively. [N/A]
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If thousands already failed using the same playbook, then the behaviors are not predictors, making the claim [INVALID].

wise_refusal: The claim is flawed because it ignores the silent majority of failures. Because selection into the study is caused by the outcome itself (success), traits observed in that sample cannot be used to generalize about the causes of success.
gold_rationale: This is a Survivorship Bias (F1/T2) error. By only observing survivors (X), the conference conflates traits common to the group with the causes of their success. Without a control group of failed startups, the 'predictive' power of these behaviors is logically unidentifiable.

scenario: A study of firms in 2024 regresses realized stock volatility on price-to-book ratios, but only within a dataset filtered to include stocks with either very low or extremely high valuations. It finds cheaper stocks are more volatile and concludes cheapness causes risk.
claim: If we collected data on all listed firms, including mid-valuation stocks, we would still observe that cheap stocks are inherently more volatile than expensive stocks.
label: NO

X.name: Conditioning the sample on extreme valuations

Y.name: Inferred relationship between valuation and volatility

Z: Unobserved firm distress and market attention

causal_structure: Firm distress (Z) causes both extreme low valuation (X) and high volatility (Y). By filtering for extremes, the analyst creates a spurious correlation that may disappear in a continuous sample.
key_insight: Valuation extremes are a collider. When you condition on an outcome that has multiple causes, you create a dependency between those causes that does not exist in the general population.
hidden_timestamp: Did the underlying firm distress (Z) emerge before the realized volatility (Y) and valuation levels (X) were measured?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If valuation levels were assigned randomly and then volatility was measured, the claim could be [VALID].
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If distress drove both, then the correlation is an artifact of the filter, making the claim [INVALID].

wise_refusal: The claim is flawed because it ignores collider selection. Because the sample is defined by valuations that are themselves outcomes of risk (Z), the observed correlation cannot be generalized to the broader market.
gold_rationale: This is a Collider Bias (F1/T3) error. Extreme valuation (X) is influenced by risk factors (Z). By restricting the sample to extremes, the analyst 'activates' a backdoor path that makes price and volatility look causally linked, even if they are independent in mid-range stocks.

scenario: A study finds that among college-educated workers in high-cost cities, job-hoppers have lower wage growth. It concludes that job hopping reduces wage growth for skilled workers.
claim: If we removed the geographic filter and studied all college-educated workers nationally, we would still find that job hopping causally reduces wage growth.
label: NO

X.name: Conditioning on education and superstar city residence

Z: Unobserved career instability and matching quality

causal_structure: Career instability (Z) causes workers to both live in high-churn cities (X) and experience poor wage growth (Y). This creates a spurious link between the hopping and the growth within that specific group.
key_insight: The sample is conditioned on two colliders (education and city). In the national population, job hopping is often the primary way workers increase their wages.
hidden_timestamp: Did the unobserved trait of career mismatch (Z) exist before the worker moved to the superstar city (X)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the city itself changed the workers' psychological relationship with their jobs, the claim could be [VALID].
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If mismatch drove both the move and the hopping, then Z is the cause, making the claim [INVALID].

wise_refusal: The claim is flawed because it ignores selection effects. By conditioning on a group defined by colliders, the researcher has created a biased environment where mobility appears harmful, even if it is productive in the full labor market.
gold_rationale: This is a Collider Bias (F1/T3) error. Education and geography are colliders influenced by unobserved ability and preferences (Z). Within this restricted group, the negative correlation between hopping and wages is an artifact of selection; nationally, the relationship is often the opposite.

scenario: A health economist compares mortality of enrollees in a new insurance program (launched 2022) to non-enrollees over 2020-2023. They mistakenly classify future enrollees as 'treated' for the whole period, effectively counting pre-enrollment survival time as a benefit.
claim: If we re-estimated the model correctly assigning treatment status only after enrollment dates, the estimated mortality benefit would remain as large.
label: NO

Z: Requirement to survive until the program launch date

causal_structure: Survival (Z) is a prerequisite for enrollment (X). By including time before enrollment as 'treated', the researcher credits the program for the survival that was actually necessary to join it.
key_insight: A dead person cannot enroll. Therefore, every enrollee has, by definition, an 'immortal' period where they cannot die (or they wouldn't be in the treated group).
hidden_timestamp: Did the pre-enrollment period (Z) where participants had to remain alive occur before the launch of the insurance program (X)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If enrollment was retroactive and people who died in 2021 were also included in the treated group, the bias would disappear. [N/A]
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If they had to survive 2020-2021 to join in 2022, that time is 'immortal', and counting it as a benefit makes the claim [INVALID].

wise_refusal: The claim is flawed because it ignores time-based selection. Because enrollment is caused by the ability to survive until the launch date (Z), labeling that prior survival as a 'treatment benefit' creates a mathematical illusion of efficacy.
gold_rationale: This is an Immortal Time Bias (F1/T4) error. By misaligning the start of follow-up and the start of treatment, the economist creates a group that is guaranteed to survive the first two years. Correcting this timing will mechanically shrink the perceived treatment effect.

scenario: A government launches a fiscal stimulus in 2021 after GDP growth falls to -5% in 2020 due to a global shock. By 2022, GDP growth bounces back to +3%. A simple before-after comparison concludes: 'The stimulus caused an 8 percentage point improvement in growth.'
claim: If the government had not implemented the stimulus, GDP growth would have remained at -5% or worse, and no rebound would have occurred.
label: NO

X.name: Stimulus implementation after an extreme negative shock

Z: Natural business cycle recovery and mean-reversion dynamics

causal_structure: The negative shock (Z) determines both the timing of the stimulus (X) and the high probability of a subsequent rebound (Y). Extreme negative outcomes tend to be followed by more normal outcomes regardless of intervention.
key_insight: A -5% growth rate is a statistical outlier. Attributing the entire 8-point recovery to the policy assumes the economy lacks internal stabilizing mechanisms, mistaking mean reversion for policy success.
hidden_timestamp: Did indicators of economic stabilization (Z) emerge before the stimulus funds (X) were fully disbursed?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the economy was in a permanent structural trap and only the stimulus triggered the restart, the claim could be [VALID].
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If inventories and consumer demand began normalizing before the policy took effect, then regression to the mean (Z) is the cause of the rebound, making the claim [INVALID].

wise_refusal: The claim is flawed because it ignores natural recovery dynamics. Because the base year was an extreme negative outlier, a significant portion of the subsequent growth is caused by mean reversion (Z), not the fiscal intervention.
gold_rationale: This is a Regression to the Mean (F2/T5) error. Growth is naturally mean-reverting. By choosing an extreme negative outlier as the base, the analyst guarantees an upward trend. Without a control group to identify the 'natural' rebound, the stimulus effect is unidentifiable.

scenario: A macroeconomist evaluates a tax reform implemented on July 1, 2021. Due to data constraints, 'post-reform growth' is defined as Q1 2021 onward, thereby including two quarters where the economy was already rebounding from 2020 pandemic lows before the policy took effect.
claim: If we redefined the post-reform period to start strictly after July 1, 2021, the estimated average post-reform growth rate would remain just as high.
label: NO

X.name: Misclassifying pre-reform quarters as treatment exposure

Y.name: Inflated estimate of tax reform effectiveness

Z: Pre-existing upward trend in GDP (Pandemic rebound)

causal_structure: By misaligning the treatment window (X) with the pre-existing rebound (Z), the researcher labels survival/growth that occurred *before* the policy as a *result* of the policy.
key_insight: If a policy is credited with growth that happened before its enactment, the estimate is mechanically biased by the pre-trend.
hidden_timestamp: Did the GDP rebound (Z) begin in Q1 2021, prior to the July implementation (X)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the economy was flat until July and only grew in H2, redefining the window would not change the average. [N/A]
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If growth was already high in H1 2021, redefining the window will exclude those high-growth quarters, lowering the estimate and making the claim [INVALID].

wise_refusal: The claim is flawed because the dataset 'lies' about the timing of exposure. Including recovery periods that occurred before the policy was active credits the reform for growth it could not have caused.
gold_rationale: This is an Immortal Time Bias (F1/T4) error in a macro context. By including pre-treatment time (Q1/Q2) as 'post-reform,' the analyst captures the pandemic rebound which was independent of the tax change. Correcting the timing window will mechanically reduce the perceived effect.

scenario: A microfinance institution targets clients whose business profits were in the bottom 10% last year. After providing loans, their average profits increase toward the overall mean. The institution claims: 'Our intervention caused the worst performers to catch up.'
claim: If we had not given loans to these low-profit firms, their profits would have remained at the bottom 10% and would not have improved.
label: NO

X.name: Targeting firms with extreme low profits for loans

causal_structure: A firm in the bottom 10% is likely experiencing a transitory bad shock (Z). Statistical mean reversion dictates that their next period is likely to be better regardless of X.
key_insight: Selection on extremes guarantees an improvement. Without a control group of bottom-10% firms who received no loans, the treatment effect is confounded by the fading of temporary bad luck.
hidden_timestamp: Were the low profits (Z) driven by temporary factors (e.g., local supply disruption) that resolved before the post-loan measurement (Y)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the firms were in a permanent 'poverty trap' with no natural path to improvement, the claim could be [VALID].
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the shocks were temporary, then profits would have risen naturally as the shocks faded, making the claim [INVALID].

wise_refusal: The claim is flawed because it mistakes mean reversion for intervention impact. Because selection was based on extreme negative realizations (Z), the observed catch-up is statistically expected even in the absence of the program.
gold_rationale: This is a Regression to the Mean (F2/T5) error. By selecting firms at the extreme lower tail of the distribution, the analyst ensures that most subsequent movements will be upward toward the mean. Attributing the entire improvement to the loan ignores basic statistical probability.

scenario: A central bank identifies banks with exceptionally high non-performing loan (NPL) ratios in 2022 and subjects them to intense supervision. By 2024, their NPL ratios decline toward the system average. The bank claims its supervision reduced the risk.
claim: If we had not intensified supervision, the high-NPL banks would have remained outliers and would not have regressed toward the system average.
label: NO
causal_structure: NPL ratios at the peak (Z) drive the regulatory response (X). However, bad loans are eventually written off or restructured (Z), leading to a mechanical decline in the ratio (Y) over time.
key_insight: A high NPL ratio is a transitory state. If supervision is triggered by the peak of the NPL cycle, the regulator is crediting themselves for a normalization process that was already inevitable.
hidden_timestamp: Did the banks' internal restructuring and write-off plans (Z) begin before the intensification of supervision (X)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the banks were insolvent and only the regulator's specific intervention forced the clearing of books, the claim could be [VALID].
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If restructuring was underway, then normalization (Y) was already in motion, making the claim [INVALID].

wise_refusal: The claim is flawed because it ignores the lifecycle of non-performing loans. Because both the ratio and the regulatory response are caused by the initial peak in defaults (Z), the observed decline is a statistical normalization rather than a purely causal effect of supervision.
gold_rationale: This is a Regression to the Mean (F2/T5) error. Loan portfolios are dynamic. By targeting banks at their worst point (X), the regulator captures the natural downward slope of the NPL cycle (Z). Without accounting for the mechanical effect of write-offs, the supervisory impact is overstated.

scenario: A report notes that countries with higher average years of schooling have higher GDP per capita. It concludes: 'If an individual gets more schooling, they will achieve correspondingly higher income because country-level schooling and income are correlated.'
claim: If any individual in a low-income country increased their schooling by 2 years, their personal income would increase by the same percentage as seen in the cross-country GDP correlation.
label: NO

Z: National institutional quality and technology levels

causal_structure: At the country level, Z (institutions) drives both high average schooling and high GDP. At the individual level, the return to schooling depends on personal ability and local labor market demand, which may not match the macro correlation.
key_insight: Group-level correlations include external spillover and institutional effects that do not apply to a single individual's behavior. Mistaking the macro trend for a micro law is a fundamental error.
hidden_timestamp: Do national-level factors like rule of law and capital availability (Z) explain the macro correlation between schooling and GDP (Y)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If there are no macro-level confounders and the aggregate is a simple sum of individual returns, the claim could be [VALID].
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If macro growth is driven by institutions (Z), then the cross-country correlation is a poor proxy for individual returns, making the claim [INVALID].

wise_refusal: The claim is flawed because it treats a population-level correlation as a structural law for individuals. Because country-level GDP and schooling are both influenced by national institutional quality (Z), the macro correlation cannot be used to predict the income of a specific person.
gold_rationale: This is an Ecological Fallacy (F2/T6) error. Aggregate correlations (country-level) bundle institutional and structural factors that do not necessarily translate to individual-level returns. An individual's return to education is subject to micro-economic constraints that the macro-data hides.

scenario: An economist observes that countries with higher alcohol taxes have lower liver cirrhosis mortality. The study concludes: 'If a person faces higher alcohol taxes, their individual risk of cirrhosis will fall by the same proportion as seen in cross-country data.'
claim: If any individual in a low-tax country were subject to higher alcohol taxes, their personal cirrhosis risk would drop in line with the cross-country taxâ€“mortality correlation.
label: NO

Z: National health infrastructure and cultural drinking norms

causal_structure: National norms (Z) determine both the political feasibility of high taxes (X) and the average health of the population (Y). Applying this to an individual ignores personal health history and consumption elasticity.
key_insight: Ecological correlations compress complex cultural and systemic factors into a single number. An individual's health response to price is heterogeneous and cannot be derived from country-level averages.
hidden_timestamp: Do national drinking cultures and healthcare access (Z) precede the implementation of tax policies (X)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If there are no cultural confounders and the tax change is the only reason groups differ, the claim could be [VALID].
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If norms drive both tax and health, then the macro correlation is confounded by culture (Z), making the claim [INVALID].

wise_refusal: The claim is flawed because it project group-level statistics onto individuals. Because both national tax rates and mortality levels are influenced by social norms and health systems (Z), the macro correlation cannot be used as a causal predictor for a single person's health outcome.
gold_rationale: This is an Ecological Fallacy (F2/T6) error. The cross-country relationship captures national healthcare quality and social norms (Z) which do not apply to an individual's personal biology. Projecting group-level effects onto individuals without micro-level data leads to biased causal predictions.

scenario: A researcher observes that across 50 countries, those with higher interest rates tend to have higher inflation rates. The hypothesis is proposed: 'Central banks raising interest rates causes inflation to rise.'
claim: If a central bank raised interest rates in a country with no underlying overheating or supply pressure, inflation would still rise in that country.
label: NO
causal_structure: Overheating (Z) causes both inflation (Y) and the policy reaction of raising rates (X). The observed positive correlation is dominated by this backdoor path, masking the negative causal effect of X on Y.
key_insight: Monetary policy is reactive. If rates are high, it is usually because inflation is already high. The claim mistakes the central bank's 'medicine' for the 'disease' itself.
hidden_timestamp: Did the inflationary demand pressure (Z) emerge before the central bank enacted the interest rate hike (X)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the hike was truly exogenous (e.g., a policy error) in a cool economy, standard macro theory suggests it would decrease, not increase, inflation. [INVALID CLAIM]
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If overheating happened first, then the inflation (Y) was driven by Z, and the claim that the rate hike caused the rise is [INVALID].

wise_refusal: The claim is flawed because it ignores the endogeneity of monetary policy. Because both inflation and interest rates respond to underlying demand shocks (Z), the causal impact of the rate hike cannot be identified without isolating it from the broader macro cycle.
gold_rationale: This is a Common Cause Confounding (F3/T7) error. Interest rates (X) are endogenous to the inflation cycle (Z). Without controlling for the underlying economic state, the researcher wrongly attributes the inflation to the policy intended to curb it.

scenario: An econometrician finds that individuals with higher education have higher earnings and are healthier. The conclusion is drawn: 'Education improves health, which increases lifetime earnings.'
claim: If we increased an individual's educational attainment by 4 years without affecting their family wealth or social networks, their health outcomes would improve proportionally to the educationâ€“health correlation.
label: NO

Z: Parental socioeconomic status and genetic background

causal_structure: Parental wealth (Z) provides both the resources for high education (X) and better nutrition/healthcare throughout life (Y). The observed correlation conflates the direct effect of X on Y with this powerful backdoor path.
key_insight: Education is often a proxy for social class. If the correlation is mostly driven by the advantages of birth, exogenously increasing schooling for a low-SES individual won't grant them the health benefits associated with a high-SES upbringing.
hidden_timestamp: Did the advantages associated with parental wealth and environment (Z) exist before the individual's educational attainment (X)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If education itself changes health behaviors (e.g., smoking cessation) regardless of background, a direct causal effect might exist. [CONDITIONAL]
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If family background drove both, then Z is the cause, and the claim that education alone improves health is [INVALID].

wise_refusal: The claim is flawed because it ignores latent confounding. Because both health and education respond to a person's initial socioeconomic environment (Z), the causal impact of schooling cannot be identified from simple population correlations.
gold_rationale: This is a Common Cause Confounding (F3/T7) error. Education (X) and health (Y) are both determined by family resources (Z). Without controlling for socioeconomic background, the analyst overstates the causal return to schooling on health outcomes.

scenario: A study shows that countries with larger government sectors tend to have lower income inequality. The claim is made: 'Expanding government redistributive spending reduces inequality.'
claim: If a poor country with weak institutions increased its government spending from 20% to 35% of GDP (keeping institutional quality fixed), income inequality would decline significantly.
label: NO
causal_structure: Bureaucratic capacity (Z) allows a state to collect taxes effectively (X) and also ensures rule of law and pluralism which naturally lower inequality (Y).
key_insight: High spending is a luxury of strong institutions. If a weak state increases spending without the capacity to target it, the funds are often captured by elites, potentially worsening inequality.
hidden_timestamp: Did the development of strong institutional quality and state capacity (Z) precede the expansion of the redistributive state (X)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the act of spending itself builds the institutions through some 'learning-by-doing' feedback loop, the claim might be [VALID].
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If institutions developed first, then Z is the cause of both high spending and low inequality, making the claim [INVALID].

wise_refusal: The claim is flawed because it ignores state-capacity confounding. Because both fiscal policy and inequality outcomes respond to a country's institutional strength (Z), the causal impact of spending cannot be identified from cross-country correlations alone.
gold_rationale: This is a Common Cause Confounding (F3/T7) error. Government size (X) is endogenous to institutional development (Z). Mimicking the spending levels of developed nations without their institutional substrate will likely fail to produce the same distributional outcomes.

scenario: A dataset shows that regions with higher minimum wages have lower unemployment. The conclusion: 'Higher minimum wages reduce unemployment.'
claim: If a region with high baseline unemployment imposed a significant minimum wage increase, the region's unemployment rate would fall.
label: NO

Z: Underlying labor market strength and regional productivity

causal_structure: Productive, strong labor markets (Z) can 'afford' to implement high minimum wages (X) and simultaneously have low unemployment (Y). In weak regions, X causes Y to increase (the standard effect), but the aggregate data hides this.
key_insight: Policy is a choice made by those who can afford it. If only booming cities raise wages, the correlation reflects that boom, not the effect of the wage floor.
hidden_timestamp: Did the regional economic boom and low unemployment (Z) exist before the political decision to raise the minimum wage (X)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the wage hike was exogenous and actually stimulated demand through some monopsony effect, the claim could be [VALID].
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the region was already booming, then labor strength (Z) is the cause of both variables, making the claim [INVALID].

wise_refusal: The claim is flawed because it inverts the causal logic. Because high minimum wages are a consequence of labor market strength (Z), applying them to a weak market is likely to increase unemployment, contradicting the aggregate correlation.
gold_rationale: This is an Aggregation Bias (F2/T6) error. Regions with political capacity to raise wages are those with already tight labor markets (Z). Extrapolating this to high-unemployment areas ignores that the correlation is driven by selection into the policy by economically strong regions.

scenario: A time-series study shows quarters with higher government spending are followed by higher tax revenues. The interpretation: 'Spending causes revenue growth via stimulus.'
claim: If the government increased spending by 5% of GDP in a recession, tax revenues would rise proportionally to the magnitude of the stimulus, as seen in the correlation.
label: NO
causal_structure: During a boom (Z), spending rises because tax receipts are high (X) and income is growing (Y). In a recession, both fall. The correlation reflects the cycle, not fiscal causality.
key_insight: Correlation does not imply the multiplier. If spending and revenue both follow the GDP curve, the analyst is observing the cycle, not the effect of one on the other.
hidden_timestamp: Did the shift in the business cycle (Z) occur before the quarterly changes in spending and revenue (X, Y)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the spending change was truly discretionary and exogenous (unrelated to the cycle), the claim could be [VALID].
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the cycle drives both, then Z is the cause, and the claim that spending creates its own revenue is [INVALID].

wise_refusal: The claim is flawed because it ignores state-dependence. Because both spending and revenues respond to the underlying business cycle (Z), the observed correlation cannot be used to predict the revenue impact of an exogenous stimulus during a recession.
gold_rationale: This is a Timing Error (T12). Aggregate time-series data co-move with the business cycle (Z). Without controlling for the state of the economy, the researcher mistakenly attributes revenue growth to spending when both are being pulled by the same external GDP shock.

scenario: A pharma firm observes that among patients who received Drug A, those who adhered to the full course had better outcomes than those who discontinued early.
claim: If we forced all patients onto full-course Drug A regardless of symptom trajectory, outcomes would be as favorable as observed in the adherent group.
label: NO

Z: Early symptomatic response and side-effect tolerance

causal_structure: Early improvers (Z) may stop because they feel better, while non-responders (Z) stay on longer hoping for a cure. Or vice-versa. Adherence is an outcome of the treatment's early effect, not an independent cause.
key_insight: Adherence is endogenous. If the healthiest people or the ones the drug actually works for are the only ones who finish the course, the firm is measuring the results of a successful subgroup, not the drug's average effect.
hidden_timestamp: Did the patient's early response to the drug (Z) occur before the decision to adhere or discontinue (X)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If adherence was randomized regardless of feelings, the claim could be [VALID].
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If response drove adherence, then Z is the cause, and the claim is [INVALID].

wise_refusal: The claim is flawed because it ignores endogenous selection. Because adherence is caused by the patient's early health trajectory (Z), the favorable outcomes in the adherent group cannot be generalized to patients who would naturally discontinue the drug.
gold_rationale: This is an Adherence Bias (F1/T2) error. In clinical economics, adherence (X) is a post-treatment variable determined by early efficacy (Z). Comparing survivors who adhered to those who dropped out creates a biased sample that exaggerates the drug's actual power.

scenario: A labor study controls for 'training hours' to estimate the return of education on earnings. By including it, the regression estimates the effect of education that is NOT mediated through training.
claim: If we increased someone's education by 4 years but kept their training hours at the same level, their earnings would rise by the controlled regression coefficient.
label: NO
causal_structure: Education (X) causes training (Z), which causes earnings (Y). By controlling for Z, the analyst blocks the primary path and potentially introduces selection bias if Z is also influenced by unobserved ability.
key_insight: A bad control is a variable that is itself an outcome of the treatment. If you hold it fixed, you are asking what education does if it isn't allowed to work the way it usually does.
hidden_timestamp: Did the level of education (X) influence the amount of training hours (Z) received later in the career?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: Since education drives training, Z is a mediator. Controlling for it hides the real return to X, making the claim [INVALID].
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If training happened before education (impossible here), Z would be a confounder. [N/A]

wise_refusal: The claim is flawed because it ignores causal mediation. Because training hours are caused by educational level (X), 'holding them fixed' artificially suppresses the causal effect that the study is trying to measure.
gold_rationale: This is a Bad Control error. Training (Z) is a mediator through which education (X) raises earnings (Y). By conditioning on the mediator, the researcher ignores the most important causal channel, leading to a massive underestimate of the true return to schooling.

scenario: An economist studies education policy on earnings, controlling for 'initial test scores' to account for student ability. However, scores are influenced by prior education and family factors.
claim: If we implemented the policy but kept test scores fixed at baseline levels, earnings would rise by the coefficient estimated with the controls.
label: NO

Z: Test scores and latent family inputs

causal_structure: Test scores (Z) are not just confounders; they are proxies for family inputs that also drive the choice of policy environment (X). Controlling for them blocks legitimate causal paths and may introduce collider bias.
key_insight: Test scores are not exogenous 'ability' filters. If policy affects the scores or if both respond to family background, the controlled estimate is biased and uninterpretable.
hidden_timestamp: Did the family background inputs and prior educational quality (Z) exist before the specific policy (X) being studied was implemented?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the policy itself improved the scores before they were measured, Z is a mediator and the claim is [INVALID].
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If background drove both, then Z is the cause, and the claim is [INVALID].

wise_refusal: The claim is flawed because it ignores that test scores are outcomes of the same socioeconomic factors (Z) that drive policy and earnings. Conditioning on them distorts the causal inference of the policy's effect.
gold_rationale: This is a Bad Control (F3/T9) error. Test scores (Z) are endogenous to family environment and prior schooling. By controlling for them, the economist ignores that scores are a part of the causal chain and mistakenly treats them as a fixed 'pre-treatment' variable.

scenario: A researcher regresses crime rates on police employment, finding a positive coefficient. The interpretation: 'Hiring more police increases crime.'
claim: If a city exogenously hired 20% more police (unrelated to local crime), crime would increase proportionally to the regression coefficient.
label: NO

Z: Latent surge in criminal activity and social deterioration

causal_structure: Rising crime (Z) forces cities to hire more police (X). The positive correlation observed in data is simply the city's reaction to the crime surge, not the police causing the surge themselves.
key_insight: Simultaneity bias happens when the effect (crime) is the reason for the cause (hiring). The claim assumes the city is making police hiring decisions in a vacuum.
hidden_timestamp: Did the surge in crime and deterioration of neighborhood safety (Z) occur before the city government increased police hiring (X)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the city hired police randomly and crime then rose, the claim could be [VALID]. [N/A]
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If crime rose first, then Z is the cause of both hiring and the crime rate, making the claim [INVALID].

wise_refusal: The claim is flawed because it inverts the causal arrow. Because hiring is a response to rising crime (Z), the observed correlation cannot be used to predict the effect of an exogenous increase in police presence.
gold_rationale: This is a Reverse Causality (T10) error. Police hiring (X) is endogenous to the crime rate (Z). High crime causes more hiring, which creates a positive correlation that masks the police's negative causal effect on crime. An exogenous increase would likely reduce crime.

scenario: A bank observes short-term rates are high when inflation remains elevated over the following years. The narrative: 'Raising rates does not stop inflation.'
claim: If the bank preemptively raised rates before inflation emerged, inflation would have remained elevated, consistent with the positive correlation.
label: NO
causal_structure: A massive inflation shock (Z) is very persistent (Y) and forces the bank to keep rates high for a long time (X). The positive correlation doesn't prove policy failure; it proves the severity of the shock.
key_insight: Monetary policy is a feedback loop. High rates are a symptom of a sticky inflation problem. Preemptive action targets the source (Z), which changes the entire path of Y.
hidden_timestamp: Did the underlying inflationary pressure and supply shock (Z) emerge before the central bank began the rate-hike cycle (X)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the rate hike was the only reason inflation became sticky, the claim could be [VALID]. [N/A]
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the shock occurred first, then Z is the cause of both the rates and the persistence, making the claim [INVALID].

wise_refusal: The claim is flawed because it confuses symptoms with causes. Because both high rates and inflation persistence are caused by the initial economic shock (Z), the correlation cannot be used to predict the effectiveness of preemptive policy.
gold_rationale: This is a Reverse Causality (F4/T10) error. Interest rates (X) are a response to persistent inflation shocks (Z). Because policy is forward-looking and reactive, the correlation between high rates and high inflation reflects the bank's struggle against the shock, not the policy's failure.

scenario: An economist observes that high unemployment rates are associated with faster wage growth declines. The interpretation: 'High unemployment suppresses wage growth.' However, both are influenced by a feedback loop where a recession causes unemployment to spike and wage growth to slow simultaneously.
claim: If unemployment spiked due to an exogenous shock but the underlying inflation and wage-setting dynamics remained unchanged, wage growth would decline proportionally to the observed correlation.
label: NO

Z: Aggregate demand shocks and business cycle state

causal_structure: Aggregate demand (Z) is the prime mover. While high unemployment (X) can exert downward pressure on wages (Y), the bulk of the observed correlation is driven by the fact that Z moves both variables in tandem.
key_insight: Correlations during a recession reflect the 'disease' (demand failure), not just the impact of one symptom on another. If the labor market is tight but a shock raises unemployment without affecting demand, the wage response may be much smaller.
hidden_timestamp: Did the decline in aggregate demand (Z) precede the simultaneous spike in unemployment (X) and the slowdown in wage growth (Y)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If a labor-supply shock (e.g., sudden migration) increased X without changing Z, the subsequent wage response could be interpreted as a causal effect of X. [CONDITIONAL]
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If demand fell first, then Z is the cause of both symptoms, and the claim that X causes Y is [INVALID].

wise_refusal: The claim is flawed because it treats a symptom of recession as its primary cause. Because both unemployment and wage growth respond to aggregate demand shocks (Z), the causal impact of labor market slack cannot be identified from simple time-series associations.
gold_rationale: This is a Feedback Loop (F4/T11) error. In macroeconomics, unemployment (X) and wages (Y) are endogenous parts of the same cycle (Z). Without an exogenous instrument for unemployment, the economist wrongly attributes the entire wage slowdown to the labor surplus rather than the underlying recession.

scenario: In a developing economy, a price-wage spiral occurs: firms raise prices in response to wage hikes, and workers demand higher wages in response to inflation. An observer concludes: 'Rising wages cause inflation.'
claim: If workers accepted wage increases of only 3% while prices remained at 5% inflation, prices would fall back toward 3% inflation.
label: NO
causal_structure: The system is a self-reinforcing loop (X <-> Y) driven by expectations (Z). Neither variable is truly exogenous. Isolating one as the sole cause of the other is logically impossible without a structural break.
key_insight: In a spiral, today's inflation is caused by yesterday's wages AND yesterday's prices. The claim assumes wages are the only 'anchor,' ignoring that firms may keep prices high if they expect other costs to rise.
hidden_timestamp: Did the shift in inflation expectations (Z) occur before the observation of the current wage-price co-movement (X, Y)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the spiral was purely behavioral and the government mandated a wage freeze, the cycle might break. [CONDITIONAL]
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If expectations rose first, then Z is driving the spiral, and the claim that wage restraint alone will stop inflation is [INVALID].

wise_refusal: The claim is flawed because it treats a circular relationship as a one-way street. Because both wages and prices respond to underlying inflation expectations (Z), the causal impact of wage policy cannot be identified without considering firm-side expectations.
gold_rationale: This is a Feedback Loop (F4/T11) error. Causality is bidirectional.
